q: Eric Schmidt said he will "focus wherever I can add the greatest value," such as partnerships and government affairs, and that he will remain "an advisor to Larry and Sergey Brin ." I have learned a ton from him over the years, Mr. Page said of Mr. Eric Schmidt in a conference call. "I can not be more excited about moving us forward, and we are really only at the beginning." But given Eric Schmidt 's success, "the board clearly wants to retain his guidance for the next four years." It's a signal to shareholders that he'll continue to steer the boat, Wise added. Eric Schmidt , 55, is being replaced as Google Inc. 's CEO by co-founder Larry Page. Both men, along with Google Inc. 's other co-founder Sergey Brin , have limited their salaries to$ 1 for

Eric Schmidt , who told CNN last year that people who don't want their homes photographed for Google Street View could "just move." Eric Schmidt also passed along this comforting gem to The Atlantic: We know where you are. We know where you've been. We can more or less know what you're thinking about. Yikes. Of course, Eric Schmidt has since been kicked upstairs to "executive chairman," and Google co-founder Larry Page will take over day-to-day operations in April. STB) is on his way out. In a memo to Microsoft employees, CEO Steve Ballmer made it clear that Muglia's departure signals a shift in the direction the company intends to pursue. I have decided that now is the time to put new leadership in place for STB. This is simply recognition that all businesses go through cycles and need new and different talent to manage through those cycles, Steve Ballmer wrote in his email to the troops. Robert Gates . "The heart-breaking thing with respect to Guantanamo is not that there's anything wrong with it, it's one of the finest prison systems in the world," said Donald Rumsfeld . What's awkward is the fact that, for whatever reason, the administration was incapable of persuading people that that was a first-class operation, that they were not torturing people, that they were not hurting people, he said. Donald Rumsfeld described it as "a fine operation," and said US military personnel working there have "taken a lot of the heat unfairly" and "deserve a lot of credit"
